content.description: This crack problem has edges that are so clean and crisp your fingers feel glued to the rock. Stand start with all tips in the crack as high as you can get them. Move straight up using the crack and the arête until you reach the top ledge. If you avoid the arête then it's a V5. The slight overhang on the lower half makes either variation pretty engaging.
content.location: Obvious finger crack on the face of the Opuntia Block. It can be seen from the road.

content.description: Stand start in the middle of the west face. Move up using positive holds and good smears.
content.location: Starts in the center of the west face. Down climb is on the northwest corner of the same face. Reference pictures for more info.

content.description: Super obvious line following the cracked dihedral on the far right side of the east face. Start with two positive holds about head high on the arête with solid feet about one foot off the ground. Move up the the dihedral onto the small ledge about ten feet up. Follow the crack up to top out!
content.protection: One pad with a decent landing.
content.location: Cross the river and come around to the east side of the boulder opposite the road. The east face stays out of the sun until early afternoon.
